Query: With the Linux "cat" command, how do I show only certain lines by number

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_17922285: How to know the number of displayed lines of the "cat" command?
so_43724421: How to display a few line from the last few lines for a given number of files?
so_24043987: Display entire line containing certain characters in Linux
Top-3 Scripts:
so_17922285: grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR}1'

count=$(grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR > "/dev/stderr"}1' 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)

grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR > "/tmp/_temp"}1'
count=$(</tmp/_temp)

so_43724421: for f in file_*
do
    echo "$f"
    tail -n 10 "$f" | grep test_result
done

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_17922285: How to know the number of displayed lines of the "cat" command?
so_30073312: Unix - show some characters in file by line number
so_13300020: Display certain line of a file and then translate to uppercase in linux
Top-3 Scripts:
so_17922285: grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR}1'

count=$(grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR > "/dev/stderr"}1' 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)

grep "anypattern" anyfile.txt | awk 'END{print NR > "/tmp/_temp"}1'
count=$(</tmp/_temp)

so_30073312: awk 'NR==line_number {print substr($0,start_position,num_of_characters_to_show)}' file

$ cat a
1234567890
abcdefghij
$ awk 'NR==2 {print substr($0,2,5)}' a
bcdef

so_28015540: $ sed '/^[^ ]\+[ ]\+[^ ]\+[ ]\+[^ ]\+$/!d' file.txt 
Hel@@lo hi 123
two three four
1 2 3333333

$ sed -nr '/^[[:space:]]*[^[:space:]]+[[:space:]]+[^[:space:]]+[[:space:]]+[^[:space:]@]+[[:space:]]*$/p' file.txt
Hel@@lo hi 123
two three four
1 2 3333333

sed -nE '/^[[:space:]]*[^[:space:]]+[[:space:]]+[^[:space:]]+[[:space:]]+[^[:space:]@]+[[:space:]]*$/p' file.txt
